questions.text: Which of the following class definitions defines a legal abstract class?

choices.label: A
choices.text: class A { abstract void unfinished() {     } }

choices.label: B
choices.text: class A { abstract void unfinished(); }

choices.label: C
choices.text: abstract class A { abstract void unfinished(); }

choices.label: D
choices.text: public class abstract A { abstract void unfinished(); }

questions.text: Which of the following declares an abstract method in an abstract Java class?

choices.label: A
choices.text: public abstract method();

choices.label: B
choices.text: public abstract void method();

choices.label: C
choices.text: public void abstract method();

choices.label: D
choices.text: public void method() {}

choices.label: E
choices.text: public abstract void method() {}

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding abstract methods is false?

choices.label: A
choices.text: An abstract class can have instances created using the constructor of the abstract class.

choices.label: B
choices.text: An abstract class can be extended.

choices.label: C
choices.text: A subclass of a non-abstract superclass can be abstract.

choices.label: D
choices.text: A subclass can override a concrete method in a superclass to declare it abstract.

choices.label: E
choices.text: An abstract class can be used as a data type.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding abstract methods is false?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Abstract classes have constructors.

choices.label: B
choices.text: A class that contains abstract methods must be abstract.

choices.label: C
choices.text: It is possible to define an abstract class that contains no abstract methods.

choices.label: D
choices.text: An abstract method cannot be contained in a nonabstract class.

choices.label: E
choices.text: A data field can be declared abstract.

questions.text: Suppose A is an abstract class, B is a concrete subclass of A, and both A and B have a no-arg constructor. Which of the following is correct?

choices.label: A
choices.text: A a = new A();

choices.label: B
choices.text: A a = new B();

choices.label: C
choices.text: B b = new A();

choices.label: D
choices.text: B b = new B();

questions.text:
What is the output of running class Test?

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    new Circle9();
  }
}

public abstract class GeometricObject {
  protected GeometricObject() {
    System.out.print("A");
  }

  protected GeometricObject(String color, boolean filled) {
    System.out.print("B");
  }
}

public class Circle9 extends GeometricObject {
  /** No-arg constructor */
  public Circle9() {
    this(1.0);
    System.out.print("C");
  }

  /** Construct circle with a specified radius */
  public Circle9(double radius) {
    this(radius, "white", false);
    System.out.print("D");
  }

  /** Construct a circle with specified radius, filled, and color */
  public Circle9(double radius, String color, boolean filled) {
    super(color, filled);
    System.out.print("E");
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: ABCD

choices.label: B
choices.text: BACD

choices.label: C
choices.text: CBAE

choices.label: D
choices.text: AEDC

choices.label: E
choices.text: BEDC

questions.text:
The java.lang.Number and its subclasses are introduced in this section. Analyze the following code.

Number numberRef = new Integer(0);
Double doubleRef = (Double)numberRef;

choices.label: A
choices.text: There is no such class named Integer. You should use the class Int.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The compiler detects that numberRef is not an instance of Double.

choices.label: C
choices.text: A runtime class casting exception occurs, since numberRef is not an instance of Double.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program runs fine, since Integer is a subclass of Double.

choices.label: E
choices.text: You can convert an int to double, so you can cast an Integer instance to a Double instance.

questions.text:
Inspect the following code.

Number[] numberArray = new Integer[2];
numberArray[0] = new Double(1.5);

choices.label: A
choices.text: You cannot use Number as a data type since it is an abstract class.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Since each element of numberArray is of the Number type, you cannot assign an Integer object to it.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Since each element of numberArray is of the Number type, you cannot assign a Double object to it.

choices.label: D
choices.text: At runtime, new Integer[2] is assigned to numberArray. This makes each element of numberArray an Integer object. So you cannot assign a Double object to it.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code. Which of the following statements is correct?

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Number x = new Integer(3);
    System.out.println(x.intValue());
    System.out.println(x.compareTo(new Integer(4)));
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because an Integer instance cannot be assigned to a Number variable.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because intValue is an abstract method in Number.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error because x does not have the compareTo method.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program compiles and runs fine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Integer i = 4.5;

choices.label: B
choices.text: Double i = 4.5;

choices.label: C
choices.text: Object i = 4.5;

choices.label: D
choices.text: Number i = 4.5;

questions.text:
Analyze the following code. Which of the following statements is correct?

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Number x = new Integer(3);
    System.out.println(x.intValue());
    System.out.println((Integer)x.compareTo(new Integer(4)));
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because an Integer instance cannot be assigned to a Number variable.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because intValue is an abstract method in Number.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error because x cannot be cast into Integer.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program has a compile error because the member access operator (.) is executed before the casting operator.

choices.label: E
choices.text: The program compiles and runs fine.

questions.text:
The java.util.Calendar and java.util.GregorianCalendar classes are introduced in this section. Analyze the following code. Which of the following statements is correct?

1. import java.util.*;
2. public class Test {
3.   public static void main(String[] args) {
4.     Calendar[] calendars = new Calendar[10];
5.     calendars[0] = new Calendar();
6.     calendars[1] = new GregorianCalendar();
7.   }
8. }

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error on Line 4 because java.util.Calendar is an abstract class.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error on Line 5 because java.util.Calendar is an abstract class.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error on Line 6 because Calendar[1] is not of a GregorianCalendar type.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program has no compile errors.

questions.text: Assume Calendar calendar = new GregorianCalendar(). __________ returns the month of the year.

choices.label: A
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.MONTH)

choices.label: B
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.MONTH_OF_YEAR)

choices.label: C
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.WEEK_OF_MONTH)

choices.label: D
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.WEEK_OF_YEAR)

questions.text: Assume Calendar calendar = new GregorianCalendar(). __________ returns the week of the year.

choices.label: A
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.MONTH)

choices.label: B
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.MONTH_OF_YEAR)

choices.label: C
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.WEEK_OF_MONTH)

choices.label: D
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.WEEK_OF_YEAR)

questions.text: Assume Calendar calendar = new GregorianCalendar(). __________ returns the number of days in a month.

choices.label: A
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.MONTH)

choices.label: B
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.MONTH_OF_YEAR)

choices.label: C
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.WEEK_OF_MONTH)

choices.label: D
choices.text: calendar.get(Calendar.WEEK_OF_YEAR)

choices.label: E
choices.text: calendar.getActualMaximum(Calendar.DAY_OF_MONTH)

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct interface?

choices.label: A
choices.text: interface A { void print() { }; }

choices.label: B
choices.text: abstract interface A { print(); }

choices.label: C
choices.text: abstract interface A { abstract void print() { };}

choices.label: D
choices.text: interface A { void print();}

questions.text: Which of the following are incorrect?

choices.label: A
choices.text: An abstract class contains constructors.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The constructors in an abstract class should be protected.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The constructors in an abstract class are private.

choices.label: D
choices.text: You may declare a final abstract class.

choices.label: E
choices.text: An interface may contain constructors.

questions.text: _______ is not a reference type.

choices.label: A
choices.text: A class type

choices.label: B
choices.text: An interface type

choices.label: C
choices.text: An array type

choices.label: D
choices.text: A primitive type

questions.text:
Show the output of running the class Test in the following code lines:

interface A {
}

class C {  
}

class D extends C {  
}

class B extends D implements A {
}

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    B b = new B();
    if (b instanceof A)
      System.out.println("b is an instance of A");
    if (b instanceof C)
      System.out.println("b is an instance of C");
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: Nothing.

choices.label: B
choices.text: b is an instance of A.

choices.label: C
choices.text: b is an instance of C.

choices.label: D
choices.text: b is an instance of A followed by b is an instance of C.

questions.text: Suppose A is an interface, B is a concrete class with a no-arg constructor that implements A. Which of the following is correct?

choices.label: A
choices.text: A a = new A();

choices.label: B
choices.text: A a = new B();

choices.label: C
choices.text: B b = new A();

choices.label: D
choices.text: B b = new B();

questions.text:
Analyze the following code:

public class Test1  {
  public Object max(Object o1, Object o2) {
    if ((Comparable)o1.compareTo(o2) >= 0) {
      return o1;
    }
    else {
      return o2;
    }
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because Test1 does not have a main method.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because o1 is an Object instance and it does not have the compareTo method.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error because you cannot cast an Object instance o1 into Comparable.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program would compile if ((Comparable)o1.compareTo(o2) >= 0) is replaced by (((Comparable)o1).compareTo(o2) >= 0).

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true?

choices.label: A
choices.text: The String class implements Comparable.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The Date class implements Comparable.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The Double class implements Comparable.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The BigInteger class implements Comparable.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code.

1. public class Test  {
2.   public static void main(String[] args) {
3.     Fruit[] fruits = {new Fruit(2), new Fruit(3), new Fruit(1)};
4.     java.util.Arrays.sort(fruits);
5.   }
6. }

class Fruit {
  private double weight;
  
  public Fruit(double weight) {
    this.weight = weight;
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because the Fruit class does not have a no-arg constructor.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a runtime error on Line 3 because the Fruit class does not have a no-arg constructor.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error on Line 4 because the Fruit class does not implement the java.lang.Comparable interface and the Fruit objects are not comparable.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program has a runtime error on Line 4 because the Fruit class does not implement the java.lang.Comparable interface and the Fruit objects are not comparable.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code.

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    java.util.Date x = new java.util.Date();
    java.util.Date y = x.clone();
    System.out.println(x = y);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: A java.util.Date object is not cloneable.

choices.label: B
choices.text: x = y in System.out.println(x = y) causes a compile error because you cannot have an assignment statement inside a statement.

choices.label: C
choices.text: x = y in System.out.println(x = y) causes a runtime error because you cannot have an assignment statement inside a statement.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program has a compile error because the return type of the clone() method is java.lang.Object.

questions.text:
The output from the following code is __________.

java.util.ArrayList<String> list = new java.util.ArrayList<String>();
list.add("New York"); 
java.util.ArrayList<String> list1 = (java.util.ArrayList<String>)(list.clone());
list.add("Atlanta"); 
list1.add("Dallas"); 
System.out.println(list1);

choices.label: A
choices.text: [New York]

choices.label: B
choices.text: [New York, Atlanta]

choices.label: C
choices.text: [New York, Atlanta, Dallas]

choices.label: D
choices.text: [New York, Dallas]

questions.text:
The GeometricObject and Circle classes are defined in this chapter. Analyze the following code. Which statements are correct?

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    GeometricObject x = new Circle(3);
    GeometricObject y = (Circle)(x.clone());
    System.out.println(x);
    System.out.println(y);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because the clone() method is protected in the Object class.

choices.label: B
choices.text: After you override the clone() method and make it public in the Circle class, the program can compile and run just fine, but y is null if Circle does not implement the Cloneable interface.

choices.label: C
choices.text: To enable a Circle object to be cloned, the Circle class has to override the clone() method and implement the java.lang.Cloneable interface.

choices.label: D
choices.text: If GeometricObject implements Cloneable and Circle overrides the clone() method, the clone() method will work fine to clone Circle objects.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.label: A
choices.text: If you compile an interface without errors, a .class file is created for the interface.

choices.label: B
choices.text: If you compile a class without errors but with warnings, a .class file is created.

choices.label: C
choices.text: If you compile a class with errors, a .class file is created for the class.

choices.label: D
choices.text: If you compile an interface without errors, but with warnings, a .class file is created for the interface.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Inheritance models the is-a relationship between two classes.

choices.label: B
choices.text: A strong is-a relationship describes a direct inheritance relationship between two classes.

choices.label: C
choices.text: A weak is-a relationship describes that a class has certain properties.

choices.label: D
choices.text: A strong is-a relationship can be represented using class inheritance.

choices.label: E
choices.text: A weak is-a relationship can be represented using interfaces.

questions.text: What is the best suitable relationship between Employee and Faculty?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Composition

choices.label: B
choices.text: Aggregation

choices.label: C
choices.text: Inheritance

choices.label: D
choices.text: None.

questions.text: Assume an employee can work for only one company. What is the best suitable relationship between Company and Employee?

choices.label: A
choices.text: None

choices.label: B
choices.text: Aggregation

choices.label: C
choices.text: Inheritance

choices.label: D
choices.text: Composition

questions.text: The relationship between an interface and the class that implements it is _____________.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Composition

choices.label: B
choices.text: Aggregation

choices.label: C
choices.text: Inheritance

choices.label: D
choices.text: None

questions.text: The Rational class in this chapter is defined as a subclass of java.lang.Number. Which of the following expressions is correct?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Rational.doubleValue();

choices.label: B
choices.text: Rational.doubleValue("5/4");

choices.label: C
choices.text: new Rational(5, 4).doubleValue();

choices.label: D
choices.text: new Rational(5, 4).toDoubleValue();

choices.label: E
choices.text: new Rational(5, 4).intValue();

questions.text:
The Rational class in this chapter extends java.lang.Number and implements java.lang.Comparable. Analyze the following code.

1. public class Test {
2.   public static void main(String[] args) {
3.     Number[] numbers = {new Rational(1, 2), new Integer(4), new Double(5.6)};
4.     java.util.Arrays.sort(numbers);
5.   }
6. }

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because numbers is declared as Number[], so you cannot assign {new Rational(1, 2), new Integer(4), new Double(5.6)} to it.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a runtime error because numbers is declared as Number[], so you cannot assign {new Rational(1, 2), new Integer(4), new Double(5.6)} to it.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error because numbers is declared as Number[], so you cannot pass it to Arrays.sort(Object[]).

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program has a runtime error because the compareTo methods in Rational, Integer, and Double classes do not compare the value of one type with a value of another type.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true?

choices.label: A
choices.text: A class should describe a single entity and all the class operations should logically fit together to support a coherent purpose.

choices.label: B
choices.text: A class should always contain a no-arg constructor.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The constructors must always be public.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The constructors may be protected.

questions.text: Which of the following is poor design?

choices.label: A
choices.text: A data field is derived from other data fields in the same class.

choices.label: B
choices.text: A method must be invoked after/before invoking another method in the same class.

choices.label: C
choices.text: A method is an instance method, but it does not reference any instance data fields or invoke instance methods.

choices.label: D
choices.text: A parameter is passed from a constructor to initialize a static data field.

choices.label: E
choices.text: All of the above.
